title: Lawmakers Move Closer to Covid-19 Relief Pact
summary: Lawmakers are hurrying to craft another aid package before the holidays and the expiration of several key aid provisions. WASHINGTON-Top congressional leaders said they were coming closer to reaching an agreement on another coronavirus relief package, broadcasting progress after months of fitful efforts to approve more aid.

title: Texas Hires Lawyers to Handle Antitrust Case Against Google
summary: Google has denied any anticompetitive behavior; a Texas suit would follow a U.S. suit. WASHINGTON-Texas's attorney general said Tuesday he is hiring two prominent law firms to handle a possible antitrust case against Alphabet Inc.'s Google, a signal that the filing of a lawsuit is likely imminent.

title: White House National Security Adviser O'Brien Cuts Trip Short to Address SolarWinds Hack
summary: O'Brien will hold meetings Tuesday and Wednesday to address suspected Russian hack of U.S. government agencies. WASHINGTON-White House national security adviser Robert O'Brien has cut short a multicountry trip to Europe to return to the U.S. to address the suspected Russian hack of government agencies, signaling growing alarm within the Trump administration about a cyber espionage campaign considered potentially one of the most damaging in years.

title: Biden Selects Pete Buttigieg as Transportation Secretary
summary: The former South Bend, Ind., mayor endorsed Biden after dropping his bid for the Democratic nomination in March. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden has selected former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, his former Democratic primary rival, to lead the Transportation Department, Mr. Biden said Tuesday.

title: Biden to Pick Granholm, McCarthy for Energy, Climate Roles
summary: Former EPA chief McCarthy will serve as national climate adviser; former Michigan Gov. Granholm to lead Energy Department. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden is planning to tap former Obama administration Environmental Protection Agency chief Gina McCarthy as national climate adviser and former Michigan Gov. Jennifer Granholm as Energy secretary, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Labor Department Finishes Fiduciary Rule for Retirement Plans
summary: But regulation affecting trillions of dollars in retirement accounts is likely to face revision by Biden administration. The Labor Department completed on Tuesday the Trump administration's fiduciary rule governing advice affecting the trillions of dollars in retirement accounts. But because the regulation won't go into effect until after President-elect Joe Biden takes office, it is likely to be revised by the new administration.

title: Air Canada Promotes Company Insider to CFO
summary: The carrier's current finance chief is set to become chief executive in February. Air Canada promoted an internal candidate to the role of the finance chief as the airline battles a severe downturn in travel due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Google's Gmail Faces Service Disruptions Again
summary: Users encounter problems a day after a wider disruption to Google services. A number of Gmail users experienced issues with the email service Tuesday, a day after more than a dozen Google services such as YouTube endured a nearly hourlong disruption.

title: Public-Sector Tech Braces for Even Tighter Budgets
summary: State budget shortfalls resulting from the pandemic threaten a push by IT leaders for improved digital services, cybersecurity. State information-technology leaders say spending on cybersecurity, digital services and broadband will be priorities in the year ahead, as the coronavirus pandemic continues to shape public-sector technology plans.

title: Mallinckrodt Shareholders Fight for Seat at Bankruptcy Bargaining Table
summary: Caught in wave of opioid lawsuits, the drugmaker wants to leave shareholders behind in chapter 11. Mallinckrodt PLC shareholders are pressing for a seat at the bankruptcy bargaining table, where the future of the drugmaker will be determined.

title: Trump Organization Ordered to Turn Over Documents to New York Attorney General
summary: President's company had tried to shield the records from a state civil fraud investigation. A New York judge Tuesday ordered the Trump Organization to hand over documents related to its sprawling Westchester County estate to the state attorney general's office as it pursues a civil fraud investigation into the president and his company.

title: Europe's Digital Power Play
summary: Tying down U.S. behemoths won't boost European competitors.. Ask not why Europe doesn't regulate digital companies more. Ask why Europe doesn't have more of its own digital companies to regulate. That is the question Brussels should have considered as it prepared the new tech regulations the European Commission unveiled Tuesday.

title: Secrets of the Oracle Prosecution
summary: A letter reveals the animus behind a dubious labor lawsuit.. We've often criticized the Labor Department's lawsuit launched in the waning days of the Obama Administration against Oracle for discriminating against women and minorities. But it turns out the prosecution was even worse than we thought-and there's a lesson here about federal misuse of race and gender as enforcement cudgels.

title: The Market the Central Bank Bought
summary: The Bank of Japan becomes the country's largest stockholder.. The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee is meeting this week, and we'll learn Wednesday if it will expand its purchases of Treasurys and private bonds. Which makes it a good moment to point out that the Bank of Japan is now that country's largest single owner of equities. This is a milestone worth marking since pressure inevitably will mount on other central banks to follow where Japan's excessively innovative monetary authorities lead.

title: Is Remote Learning an 'Easy A'?
summary: Students discuss whether the pandemic has raised or lowered colleges' standards.. Editor's note: This week's Future View asks whether pandemic-related measures in higher education have lowered colleges' standards. Next week we'll ask, "Will you take the vaccine as soon as it's available to you? Why or why not?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Dec. 22. The best responses will be published that night.

title: An Intelligent Discussion About Race and IQ Is Possible
summary: James Flynn approached one of social science's most controversial topics with logic and empiricism.. This cruelest of years has claimed the life of another consequential scholar whose passing warrants some reflection.

title: The Trouble With Facial Recognition Doesn't Justify a Ban
summary: It's helped find thousands of dangerous criminals. Reasonable limits can prevent abuse and error.. Massachusetts Gov. Charlie Baker was right not to sign legislation banning the use of facial-recognition technology by law-enforcement and public agencies statewide. The technology has come under fire over its potential for misuse and embedded racial biases. San Francisco and Oakland, Calif., have already banned its use by government agencies. But on Thursday Mr. Baker sent back to the Legislature a police-reform bill that included a blanket moratorium on facial-recognition systems, citing the technology's usefulness in catching perpetrators of egregious crimes.

title: New Volkswagen CFO Tasked With Boosting Efficiencies
summary: Arno Antlitz is set to take over from current finance chief Frank Witter in mid-2021. Volkswagen AG's new finance chief, a company insider, will be tasked with boosting efficiencies to free up funds as the German auto giant looks to ramp up its spending on electric vehicles.

title: Notable & Quotable: A Scholar
summary: 'The real aim for our ire should be @jamestaranto the editor of their op-ed page.'. A Dec. 13 Twitter thread by Sarah Parcak, a professor of archaeology at the University of Alabama at Birmingham and a fellow at the John Simon Guggenheim Foundation:

title: 'The Speed Game' Review: Fast Break Forever
summary: A veteran coach reflects on Kareem, Magic and a style of play. The key is never to let up. Slowing down only gives the other team a moment to rest.. The speed game is basketball in its most simple form. It requires players, first and foremost, to run as fast as they can from tipoff to final whistle. Passing, shooting and rebounding are important but secondary. So is defense. Speed rules.

title: Vaccines vs. Lockdowns
summary: Science triumphed but shouldn't we have cut corners and moved faster?. Charlie Baker has become my model of a pandemic governor. Twice I've commended him for admitting, as early as April, that his state's contact-tracing effort was mainly a show so voters would see that Massachusetts wasn't sitting on its hands. In November, his outdoor mask-wearing mandate was panned as unscientific and unenforceable. He acknowledged as much, saying it was a signal, a new way to get the public's attention.

title: Coercion in Xinjiang's Cotton Fields
summary: The West needs wider controls on Chinese imports produced with forced labor.. 'In the past, my lazy thoughts . . . were serious. Now, I finally understand that the happiest thing is to use the money I earn with my hard-working hands and my sweat."

title: Biden Visits Georgia to Rally Support in Runoffs
summary: President-elect urges state's voters to give him working majority in Senate at start of administration. President-elect Joe Biden sought Tuesday to galvanize early voting in Georgia's pivotal Senate runoff elections, imploring Democrats to help give him a working majority at the start of his administration.

title: What Will We Do Without Trump?
summary: A reckoning for resistance media.. There's an emerging media narrative that Joe Biden is more difficult for the press to cover than Donald Trump because Mr. Biden allegedly has superior character and therefore generates fewer scandals. Accepting this spin naturally requires one to ignore the Biden family influence-peddling business. But the fear among media executives about their own businesses is real. Bashing Donald Trump has been profitable. Can you hold an audience by lauding Joe Biden?

title: Retail Tycoon Nygard Indicted in Sex-Trafficking Probe
summary: Retail tycoon arrested in Canada; charges in an indictment unsealed by Manhattan federal prosecutors. Canadian fashion and retail mogul Peter Nygard was charged with sex trafficking and racketeering, according to an indictment unsealed in Manhattan federal court Tuesday.

title: Census Estimates U.S. Population Growth Slowest Since the 1930s
summary: Census Bureau released population estimate ahead of results of 2020 census count that wrapped up in October. The U.S. population has grown about 8% over the past decade to more than 332 million people, according to a Census Bureau analysis released before the results of the decennial count.

title: Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker Cuts $700 Million From State Budget
summary: State faces $3.9 billion budget shortfall, including $2 billion from Covid-19 slowdown. Illinois Gov. J.B. Pritzker on Tuesday announced $711 million in budget cuts to address a $3.9 billion shortfall, including $2 billion in lost revenue from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: States, Cities and the Gigantic Covid Bailout
summary: Shouldn't some care be exercised in how we give money to the politicians?. William A. Galston tugs on heartstrings to make the case that "States and Cities Deserve Taxpayer Support" (Politics & Ideas, Dec. 9). But a Covid relief bill without state and local aid still would provide most of the emergency funding that he says is needed for extra unemployment benefits, costs related to vaccines and help for small businesses. Mr. Galston doesn't mention that tax revenues in many states have fallen less than was initially expected in fiscal year 2020.

title: Oregon Lawmakers Ignore Oregon, U.S. Law
summary: 'The dream of a Nation of equal citizens in a society where race is irrelevant to personal opportunity and achievement would be lost in a mosaic of shifting preferences based on inherently unmeasurable claims of past wrongs.'. Regarding James Huffman's "Oregon's Segregated Covid Relief Fund Is Blatantly Unconstitutional" (Cross Country, Dec. 5): The Oregon Cares Act provision allotting public money exclusively to black-owned businesses not only violates the U.S. Constitution, it also violates Oregon's Constitution. In the latter, Article 1, Section 20 states: "No law shall be passed granting to any citizen or class of citizens privileges, or immunities, which, upon the same terms, shall not equally belong to all citizens."

title: U.S. Stocks Rise as Investors Track Stimulus Talks
summary: Markets reflecting muted optimism that lawmakers will reach a deal on a relief package before year end. U.S. stocks climbed Tuesday as investors welcomed signs of progress in negotiations over an economic relief package in Washington.

title: Between God and Proper Insurance Coverage
summary: Many times the real issue is accepting the cost of the decisions we've made when an unfortunate loss occurs.. In "Some Acts Of God Are Better Than Others" (op-ed, Dec. 3), Bert Stratton writes of an "unfortunately high" deductible of $5,000 for his commercial property insurance, and complains about the many expenses he had to pay after a tree fell onto one of his apartment buildings: brickwork, roof repairs, gutter work, new windows, tree removal, emergency board-up and temporary living expenses for tenants.

title: Mexico Passes Law Restricting Foreign Security Agents
summary: U.S. says measure risks crippling bilateral efforts to fight drug gangs. MEXICO CITY-President Andrés Manuel López Obrador's ruling party pushed through a new law Tuesday curbing the role of foreign law-enforcement officers in Mexico, a move the U.S. believes will cripple bilateral efforts to battle powerful drug cartels.

title: 'McCartney III' by Paul McCartney Review: Songs From a Homebound Beatle
summary: His tour canceled owing to Covid-19, the musician put together an album at home in England on which he plays all the instruments and displays a still vibrant compositional flair..

title: 'The Stand' Review: A Dystopia for Today and Tomorrow
summary: This adaptation of a Stephen King novel about a pandemic is especially timely in the age of Covid, but also stands up as a lasting work in the genre.. The classics of dystopian fiction have often been born of an unhappy vision, but they've always been the product of uncluttered logic: Take an existing problem to its possible end, imagine the worst and, voilà, you have the perpetual war of "Nineteen Eighty-Four," the ultra-violence of "A Clockwork Orange," the reproductive tyranny of "A Handmaid's Tale"-and the pandemic of "The Stand," whose arrival right now as a nine-part miniseries seems more than a bit uncanny, morbidly fascinating and in somewhat questionable taste.

title: Pfizer Expands Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout Across the U.S.
summary: More front-line health-care workers receive the first dose of the shot as hospitals devise rationing methods for limited supplies. More U.S. hospitals on Tuesday began receiving shipments of the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE , with doctors and nurses being inoculated for the first time.

title: Saudi Arabia Reins In Spending to Contain Deficit
summary: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman will have to cut back on his outsize projects meant to diversify the economy. Saudi Arabia plans to spend less next year to rein in a pandemic-induced budget deficit, pursuing austerity even as a rally in oil prices signals a higher demand for crude and a global economic recovery.

title: Mexican Congress Puts Off Vote on Controversial Central Bank Bill
summary: Bill would require the Bank of Mexico to buy excess foreign cash held by banks. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's lower house of congress on Tuesday postponed debate on a controversial bill that bankers and critics said would jeopardize the central bank's autonomy by requiring it to buy foreign currency in cash that banks are unable to put into the financial system.

title: Facebook to Allow Political Ads for Georgia Runoffs
summary: Social-media giant to maintain broader blackout on political ads unconnected to Jan. 5 Senate races. Facebook Inc. said it would allow political ads for the Georgia runoff elections starting Wednesday but would maintain a broader temporary blackout for U.S. ads about social issues, elections or politics as part of its efforts to curb misinformation.

title: Gun Maker Smith & Wesson Sues New Jersey
summary: Democratic attorney general is seeking evidence of fraudulent marketing by firearms manufacturer, according to lawsuit. Smith & Wesson Brands Inc. one the nation's largest gun makers, filed suit Tuesday to block a subpoena from the New Jersey attorney general seeking information about its advertising practices.

title: Winter Storm to Test New York City's Outdoor Dining
summary: Nor'easter could prove worrisome for restaurants with outside structures set up during pandemic. Having already weathered myriad challenges this year because of the coronavirus pandemic, New York City's restaurants are now facing a nor'easter set to arrive Wednesday.

title: 'The Art of Political Murder' Review: Justice Shattered Then Served
summary: A documentary looks into the killing of a Guatemalan bishop who had exposed military crimes.. Based on novelist Francisco Goldman's 2007 work of investigative nonfiction (subtitled "Who Killed the Bishop?"), "The Art of Political Murder" is a satisfying portrait of courage, corruption and the murderous deep state that operated inside Guatemala, a country the average American ought to know a bit more about given our history there. What the film fails to mention-notably, the CIA coup that precipitated the 35-year civil war at the center of the story, and the current crisis that is driving climate refugees to our southern border-seem like glaring omissions in this troubled history. But the film's purpose is otherwise: to prove that justice can prevail, however briefly, even in an atmosphere as poisonous as the one portrayed.

title: 'Wilhelm Kempff Edition' Review: A Classical Colossus
summary: An 80-CD set of the German pianist's recordings abounds with thoughtful interpretations, including renditions of the complete piano sonatas of Beethoven and Schubert..

title: Offenders (Wednesday Crossword, December 16)
Fashion in 2020: Prabal Gurung on What This Year Will-and Won't-Change
summary: The designer talks about sustainability, sweatpants, pajamas, runway shows and the future of luxury. High fashion fell out of fashion in 2020.

title: Fed Says It Now Has Formal Membership in Global Climate Finance Group
summary: Joining concludes the Fed's status as a lone holdout from a group that counts the European Central Bank, Bank of Japan, Bank of Canada and many others as members. The Federal Reserve said Tuesday it had formally joined an international effort of central banks and financial regulators aimed at mitigating climate change risks.

title: U.K. Watchdog Fines Barclays Units $34.7 Million
summary: Barclays said it has since implemented changes to its systems, processes and training and sought to redress customers. A top U.K. regulator has levied a £26 million ($34.7 million) fine on Barclays PLC-related units over the treatment of customers that fell into arrears or went through a difficult financial situation.

title: A Simple Framework for Financial Advice
summary: A new Labor Department rule dovetails with last year's SEC guidance to ensure that individual investors receive recommendations that are in their best interest.. Today the U.S. Department of Labor published a new rule that will help ensure American workers and retirees have access to high-quality investment advice at a fair price. The Labor Department's action dovetails with a package of investor-oriented measures adopted last year by the Securities and Exchange Commission. For the first time, our agencies are aligned on a coherent framework centered on ensuring that American workers and retirees receive advice in their best interest, across the spectrum of investment professionals and account types.

title: Are 'Color of the Year' Pronouncements Actually Helpful?
summary: Annually, Pantone and major paint brands choose supposedly zeitgeisty hues, to great fanfare. Here, design pros debate the tradition's merits.. For the recurring series, That's Debatable, we take on a contentious issue of the day and present two spirited arguments-one in favor and other emphatically opposed. Previous installments from the series are here.

title: Short-Term Oil-Demand Outlook in Rich Countries Is Bleak
summary: The International Energy Agency said it would be several months before Covid-19 vaccinations begin to lift oil demand. LONDON-It will be several months before coronavirus vaccinations start to boost global oil demand, with the recovery in some of the world's wealthy countries "going backwards" this quarter, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday.

title: Georgia to Review Mail-In Ballot Signatures to Boost Confidence in Elections
summary: Audit of signed envelopes won't change outcome of presidential race in state, top official says. Georgia will audit signatures submitted by absentee voters in one county, after President Trump and his allies called for such a review as they continued to question President-elect Joe Biden's victory in the state.

title: Jeff Tweedy on Covid-19-and Its Impact on Live Music
summary: The Wilco frontman believes live music will return, but a lot of venues will be gone. Like most musicians, Wilco's Jeff Tweedy had his 2020 planned out. Wilco, which has sold millions of albums, had a world tour planned. But the pandemic set the music business-and especially the concert-tour industry, which accounts for the livelihoods not just of musicians and their road crews but of local promoters, tour-bus operators, down to the small clubs that are hurting most of all-on its ear.

title: A Divided Nation: One Psychiatrist's Advice on Lowering the Temperature
summary: Resume Subscription. Dr. Samantha Boardman (@sambmd) is a clinical assistant professor of psychiatry and assistant attending physician at Weill-Cornell Medical College in New York City. She blogs at PositivePrescription.com.

title: European Bank Dividend Ban Lifted, but Restrictions Remain
summary: European banks can resume dividends next year, cautioned not to go overboard on staff bonuses. The European Central Bank said Tuesday that lenders can restart limited dividend payments next year following a nine-month ban and told banks to be prudent about bonuses given the economic crisis caused by the pandemic.

title: How Nostalgia (and Snoop Dogg) Sparked a Retro Hockey-Jersey Craze
summary: From Adidas's ongoing partnership with the NHL to styles by streetwear labels like Supreme, throwback jerseys are infiltrating the fashion world. ONE OF the more memorable moments in the history of the Pittsburgh Penguins hockey franchise didn't occur in Pittsburgh. Or even inside an ice rink. No, this landmark event unfolded somewhere in Southern California in 1994, when the syrup-voiced rapper Snoop Dogg wore a black-and-yellow Penguins jersey to appear in the video for "Gin & Juice."

title: A $33 Million Cash Penthouse Sale Gives Miami's Condo Market a Jolt
summary: A private equity executive from New York bought the three-floor apartment at the boutique building known as the Arte, according to the building's developer. A penthouse atop a new boutique luxury condo building in Miami has sold for $33 million in cash, representing a major sale for the city's lagging condo market.

title: Covid-19 Vaccinations Begin in New Jersey
summary: About 76,000 doses will be available this week for front-line hospital workers and long-term care facilities. Covid-19 vaccinations for front-line health-care workers have begun at New Jersey hospitals nine months after the state recorded its first infection of the pandemic.

title: Giannis Antetokounmpo Decides to Stay in Milwaukee
summary: The Greek star surprised the league by signing a five-year, $228 million deal with the Bucks that takes him off next summer's free agent market.. The biggest question hanging over this NBA season now has an unexpected answer: Giannis is staying.

title: FDA Sets Stage for Moderna Vaccine Authorization
summary: Second major U.S. coronavirus vaccine could possibly be shipped by this weekend. The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that the Covid-19 vaccine developed by Moderna Inc. was "highly effective," setting the stage for an emergency authorization later this week that would add a second vaccine to the arsenal against the pandemic.

title: Verishop Brings Group Video Shopping to Its E-Commerce Platform
summary: The feature lets friends shop together over video and look at each other's picks in a shared shopping bag. Verishop Inc., a social e-commerce platform that sells lifestyle goods, is introducing a live group shopping feature on its mobile app.

title: Vol. 33, No. 11: A New Era
summary: Most Popular News. The election is over (right?), but in its wake, here are what we hope are timely reminders about how we talk about the economy and about Washington.

title: Credit Suisse Bets on Managing More Rich People's Money
summary: Chief Executive Thomas Gottstein laid out his vision for the Swiss bank, which has struggled to please investors in recent years. Credit Suisse Group AG's new chief executive said managing rich people's money will be a priority for the bank, setting a target to boost wealth-management profits by at least a quarter in the coming years.

title: VW Board Backs CEO's Electric-Car Focus
summary: Agreement puts labor tensions to rest for now, boosting VW shares. BERLIN- Volkswagen AG shares rose nearly 8% on Tuesday after the car maker's top shareholders and union leaders publicly backed Chief Executive Herbert Diess's strategy to refocus the company on electric vehicles.

title: Big Pharma Passes Its Annual Checkup
summary: Upbeat outlooks from AbbVie and Lilly don't depend on coronavirus drugs, which should have investors encouraged. Big pharma is expecting a healthy 2021. Importantly for investors, that bright future doesn't necessarily depend on the course of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: A New Way to Lead the Free World
summary: The authoritarian tide has risen, but a global alliance of democracies would help turn it back.. In 2021 the U.S. and its allies have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to reverse global democratic retreat and put autocracies like Russia and China on the back foot. That will happen if major democracies unite in the pursuit of freedom.

title: Top SEC Markets Regulator to Step Down
summary: Brett Redfearn will leave his job as director of the SEC's trading and markets division at the end of December. The Securities and Exchange Commission's top official for the oversight of exchanges, brokers and high-speed trading firms is stepping down at the end of December, concluding a three-year tenure marked by clashes with the stock exchanges he regulated.

title: Institutions Saved the 2020 Election
summary: Trump may refuse to concede, but the judiciary and the states did their duty.. For a year we have been bombarded with analyses-some sober, others less so-about how institutions could be abused to subvert the will of the people and award President Trump a second term that he hadn't won. Now that the Electoral College has rendered its verdict, let's assess these warnings.

title: Bucatini all'Amatriciana
summary: And it's easy to see why. With its winning combination of tomatoes, guanciale and just a hint of chile, bucatini all'Amatriciana hits just the right balance of bright and rich, bold and nuanced.. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Iranian Oil Exports Rise as Tehran Circumvents Sanctions, Finds New Buyers
summary: Sales have risen but remain sharply down since the U.S.'s 'maximum pressure' campaign began. LONDON-Iran has circumvented U.S. sanctions and exported more oil to China and other countries in recent months, providing a lifeline for its struggling economy and undermining the Trump administration's so-called maximum pressure campaign against Tehran.

title: This Quick Pasta Recipe Is a Roman Classic
summary: And it's easy to see why. With its winning combination of tomatoes, guanciale and just a hint of chile, bucatini all'Amatriciana hits just the right balance of bright and rich, bold and nuanced.. WHEN TOMATOES and pork fat come together in a particular way, it's magic-also known as all'Amatriciana, the classic Roman pasta sauce. Chef Rebecca Wilcomb of Gianna in New Orleans has spent a lifetime learning to appreciate the subtleties of this simple dish. "There should be balance between the fat and acid," she said. "The fat should shape the mouthfeel, and its smoky flavor should be in the background."

title: Francis Fukuyama on the State of Democracy in 2020 and Beyond
summary: Resume Subscription. The year 2020 brought us mostly bad news regarding the state of global democracy, though there were some preliminary signs that things might yet turn around.

title: High-End City Dining Turns to Suburban Delivery During the Pandemic
summary: Meals from elite urban restaurants are traveling long distances to reach customers. For months, Kate and Ben Masino had failed to find a time for the 40-minute drive from their home in Devon, Pa., to Philadelphia's Fork restaurant for a date night. But in the midst of the pandemic, the couple found the next best thing: They ordered Fork's $90 champagne-braised chicken for two, and picked it up at a local business just five minutes from their home.

title: Teacher Shortage Compounds Covid-19 Crisis in Schools
summary: Resume Subscription. PHOENIX-As if the pandemic weren't disruptive enough, many American schools are facing a growing shortage of teachers.

title: U.S. Industrial Production Rose 0.4% in November
summary: Output rises 0.4% but remains below pre-pandemic levels. A seventh straight month of manufacturing gains helped drive a November rise in U.S. industrial production as the nation's auto and parts plants increased output.

title: Europe's New Tech Regulations Will Bite, Eventually
summary: U.S. tech giants face a growing host of new rules in the region intended to change how they operate and grow. Investors have gotten used to shrugging off Europe's efforts to regulate U.S. tech giants. The point at which they will be forced to pay closer attention may not be quite here, but it is drawing inexorably nearer.

title: Jermaine Fowler on Becoming 'Seriously Funny'
summary: The 'Coming 2 America' actor and comedian was inspired to perform stand-up after watching 'Eddie Murphy Raw'. Jermaine Fowler, 32, is an actor and comedian who starred in the film "Sorry to Bother You." He will co-star with Eddie Murphy in "Coming 2 America," a movie sequel, due out March 5 on Amazon Prime. He spoke with Marc Myers.

title: Suspected Russian Hack Went Undetected for Months
summary: The hack of U.S. agencies and firms was met with alarm by current and former intelligence officials and others. WASHINGTON-A suspected Russian hack of U.S. government agencies and private businesses across the globe festered for months, going largely undetected by the Trump administration and cybersecurity firms until the past week, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Congress Eyes Targeted Coronavirus Aid for Small Businesses
summary: Proposals would focus on smaller firms that can show they have been hurt by economic downturn. WASHINGTON-Lawmakers considering a fresh round of financial aid for small businesses are focusing on firms with fewer employees that could show they have been hurt by the pandemic-triggered downturn, addressing criticisms that dogged the Paycheck Protection Program.

title: Europe Advances Review of Pfizer Vaccine as Pressure Mounts
summary: U.S., Canada and U.K. have started vaccinating, but the region where the Pfizer-BioNTech shot was developed is still waiting for it. The European Union's chief drug regulator will accelerate its review of a Covid-19 vaccine after coming under pressure from some governments to authorize the shot, as the continent struggles to contain a wave of cases ahead of the Christmas period.

title: Anna Wintour Promoted to Condé Nast Chief Content Officer
summary: Longtime editor to take charge of global editorial operations after a year punctuated by layoffs and diversity issues. Anna Wintour, long one of the most influential editors in the magazine world, is about to get even more powerful.

summary: Resume Subscription. Candace Thompson, manager of the Stuyvesant Cove Park in lower Manhattan, was pulling on a giant bindweed one day when a woman eating lunch nearby offered some advice.

summary: Resume Subscription. Where is all the action this holiday season? At the area's shipping ports. They are bustling. They are bananas. They are bursting with imports and record truck traffic rumbling through to haul it away.

title: For the Retail Industry, 2020 Was a Wild Ride
summary: Resume Subscription. Changes have been coming to the retail sector for years. But in 2020, with the onslaught of the Covid-19 pandemic, the industry received a ticket to the Fury 325 roller coaster.

title: Boko Haram Again Kidnaps Hundreds of Nigerian Students
summary: Resume Subscription. MAIDUGURI, Nigeria-Six years after the abduction of 276 schoolgirls ignited the global #BringBackOurGirls campaign, Nigeria is again reeling from a mass kidnapping, this time of more than 300 boys.

title: The Wacky Rebels of Minor League Baseball Go Legit
summary: The St. Paul Saints, an independent alternative to the big-league Minnesota Twins, will become part of the Twins organization in baseball's overhaul of the minor leagues.. The St. Paul Saints have thrived in a staid, tradition-bound industry for more than a quarter-century because of their fierce commitment to the unconventional and their embrace of the absurd.

title: Zara's Owner Will Feel the Chill This Winter
summary: Fast-fashion chain's rapidly growing online business can only partly offset a fresh wave of store closures. Zara's owner is having to shut stores again in the crucial run up to Christmas. The fashion retailer's fast-growing online business may not patch the hole as well as might be hoped.

title: Take-Two, Occidental Petroleum, Moderna: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: U.S. stock futures ticked higher as investors welcomed signs of progress on stimulus. Here's what we are watching as markets kick into gear Tuesday.

summary: Butch Graham shows off the rebuilt land-speed racer, 'City of Salt Lake.'. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Holiday Gift Guide for Music Geeks-From a Music Geek
summary: The best presents for the person who's always listening to Spotify or recording their own beats.. Whether you're shopping for a hardcore audiophile or just seeking some serenity through a new pair of sleek headphones, this holiday gift guide is for you. WSJ.'s resident audio expert, creative director Magnus Berger, lays out his suggestions for the music fans in your life, from those who have always loved rocking out to those who used their time in isolation this year to finally pick up that guitar that's been gathering dust in the corner. Check out the full list below and check back with WSJ. throughout the holiday season for all of our highly curated, super-specific gift guides.

title: Sending Bibles and K-Pop to North Korea Can Now Land You in a South Korean Jail
summary: Sending leaflets or other materials into North Korea without Seoul's permission will be punishable with a fine or imprisonment. SEOUL-For years, activist groups in South Korea have sent everything from Bibles to K-pop across the border to the North. Now that could cost them up to three years in prison and a $27,000 fine.

title: Want Your Gifts to Arrive by Christmas (Without Paying Extra)? Now's the Time
summary: FedEx, UPS are managing surge in packages with strict limits on shippers, creating backlogs for Costco and others. FedEx Corp. and United Parcel Service Inc. have largely kept up with the record onslaught of packages since Thanksgiving, though that is in part because of efforts to lighten their loads.

title: Lamar Jackson Cramps, Comes Back and Saves the Ravens' Season
summary: The reigning MVP missed most of the fourth quarter while his team lost the lead. He returned to deliver a thrilling win in a frenetic final two minutes. There were two minutes left in Monday night's showdown between the Baltimore Ravens and Cleveland Browns when a game that had already been historic became historically nutty. That's when Lamar Jackson scampered back onto the field after a lengthy absence to save Baltimore's season.

title: Twitter Fined Over EU Privacy Law
summary: $546,000 fine for late notification of a data breach took nearly two years to decide. Two-and-a-half-years after going into effect, the European Union's new privacy law has its first fine for a U.S. tech company in a cross-border case-an overdue development, critics say.

title: Schools Work to Speed Up Internet in Rural Homes
summary: Resume Subscription. Laura Gomez's two children were using her smartphone's hotspot to log in to remote school early this fall, but the video calls often dropped. The connection was so weak the children couldn't always see or hear their teachers.

title: U.S. Manufacturing: 2020 Was the Bottom of a Long Decline
summary: Resume Subscription. The U.S. manufacturing industry has experienced a lifetime of trauma over the past two decades-but we believe 2020 marks the bottom of that long and high-profile decline.

title: Huge Challenge Awaits Biden's Coronavirus Czar
summary: Former Obama adviser helped fix Affordable Care Act website after flawed launch. WASHINGTON-A crisis awaits Jeffrey Zients.

title: Co-Working Volatility Is Making the Office Market More Precarious
summary: Vacancies are starting to soar, as many companies work remotely. Empty co-working spaces are helping push office vacancies in big cities to levels not seen in decades, threatening the commercial-property sector's reputation as a haven for investors.

title: Japan's Asteroid Mission Retrieves Large Sample
summary: Scientists find crumbly samples of the asteroid Ryugu in capsule, secure first sample of extraterrestrial gases. TOKYO-Japan's space agency said it recovered far more black dirt than it was targeting from the asteroid Ryugu, confirming the success of its Hayabusa2 mission nine days after it delivered its payload to the Australian outback.

title: Cyberattack Began With Ubiquitous Software Firm
summary: SolarWinds provides the tools many companies use to manage their computer networks. That's what made the hack so pernicious.. The widespread and monthslong hack of the U.S. government and some of America's biggest corporations was enabled by an unlikely source: a little-known Austin, Texas, software company called SolarWinds Corp. that until this week was a household name only to computer network administrators.

title: The Chainsmokers and Tony Hawk Back Public.com
summary: The app lets people buy fractions of stock with relatively small amounts of money, and also share their experiences and views on investing. The Chainsmokers have taken an interest in finance, and hope that their latest investment will entice fans to follow.

title: Marriott Lays Off Hundreds of Workers at Times Square Hotel
summary: Company tells 850 employees to prepare for March 12 end date, as Covid-19 pummels New York's hotel industry. Marriott International Inc. is permanently laying off 850 employees from its hotel in Times Square, another sign that the hotel industry in New York City remains significantly hobbled by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Chinese Stimulus Won't Do Heavy Lifting in 2021
summary: The beginning of a global cyclical uptick might seem like a great time to own heavy industrial shares, but that part of China's recovery is already long in the tooth. Beijing's stimulus policies this year have been restrained by past standards, and certainly compared with those in the U.S. and Europe. Now, with consumers spending again and private investment recovering, even that modest extra gas for the economy will start to burn away.

title: New York Aims to Discover if Covid-19 Spreads on Subways
summary: Nation's largest transit agency launches study with Homeland Security and MIT. Transit officials in New York are teaming up with the Department of Homeland Security and Massachusetts Institute of Technology to study how to reduce the spread of the new coronavirus on buses and trains.

title: Real Estate's Biggest Losers Enjoy a One-Month Stock Bounce
summary: Share prices for hotels, retail and office landlords have jumped on promising Covid-19 vaccine results. Some of the worst performing real-estate stocks this year are finally having their moment.

title: High-Frequency Traders Get Even Speedier
summary: Resume Subscription. High-frequency traders are using an experimental type of cable to speed up their systems by billionths of a second, the latest move in a technological arms race to execute stock trades as quickly as possible.

title: Fannie, Freddie Privatization Call Likely to Be Left to Biden
summary: Mnuchin says Treasury is not focused on legal move to privatize Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac before President Trump leaves office. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden's election victory has likely ended the Trump administration's efforts to return Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to private hands.

title: Putin Acknowledges Biden's Election Win for First Time
summary: Russia's president says he is ready to cooperate with the incoming Biden administration. MOSCOW-Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulated President-elect Joe Biden on his election win after it was confirmed by the Electoral College, but some senior Russian officials said they were doubtful that the coming change in the White House would improve the antagonistic relationship between the two nuclear powers.

title: China Economy Continues Recovery Despite Covid-19 Surge Elsewhere
summary: Industrial output, investment and consumer spending all grew at faster paces in November. BEIJING-China's economic activity extended its momentum in November with an across-the-board recovery, putting the world's second largest economy on stronger footing as it approaches the end of a tumultuous year.

title: More Republicans in Congress Now Say Joe Biden Is President-Elect
summary: Lawmakers' comments come as state electors made Joe Biden's victory official. WASHINGTON-Many top Republican senators and close allies of President Trump said they now view Democrat Joe Biden as the next president, after more than a month of unsuccessful GOP efforts to get courts and state officials to overturn the election results.

title: A-Rod Swings for Fences With Hotel Real-Estate Fund
summary: Former Major League Baseball MVP Alex Rodriguez, now a real-estate mogul, joins a $650 million hotel fund. Baseball legend Alex Rodriguez is teaming with a Miami private-equity firm to invest more than a half-billion dollars in buying or developing hotels at a time when the industry has been ravaged by the pandemic.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
